listDisplay.primary: Ahura Mazda - The Wise Lord, Supreme Creator

name: Ahura Mazda
subtitle: The Wise Lord, Supreme Creator

attributes.sacred animals: Bull (symbol of creation), White horse, Eagle
attributes.titles: Wise Lord, Lord of Wisdom, Creator of All, Uncreated Creator, Spenta Mainyu

summary: Also known as ‚ö° Ahura Mazda. Associated with Wise Lord, Lord of Wisdom, Creator of All. Known by the epithets: Wise Lord.

search.searchableText: ahura mazda the wise lord, supreme creator ahura mazda ahura mazda

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: Ahura Mazda is the wise lord, supreme creator in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Ahura Mazda (Ohrmazd in Middle Persian) is the uncreated, omniscient, supreme deity of Zoroastrianism. He existed eternally in infinite light above the Void, possessing complete knowledge of past, present, and future. He is the source of all good creation and the ultimate embodiment of Asha (Truth/Righteousness).
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Creator of all good things. He first created the world in spiritual form (menog), then manifested it in material form (getig). He emanated the seven Amesha Spentas as aspects of his divine nature to protect and govern creation.
mythologyNarrative.eschatology: At the end of time (Frashokereti), Ahura Mazda will achieve complete victory over evil, purifying all creation and establishing eternal paradise.

dualism.nature: Ethical/Cosmic Dualism - two primordial spirits who made opposite moral choices
dualism.conflict: Ahura Mazda chose Asha (Truth), Angra Mainyu chose Druj (Lie). Their cosmic struggle defines existence.
dualism.stance: Ahura Mazda embodies light, wisdom, creation, order, and life.
dualism.resolution: Good is destined to triumph. Evil will be annihilated at Frashokereti.
dualism.humanRole: Humans must choose to follow Asha, actively participating in the cosmic struggle through good thoughts, words, and deeds.

practices: Fire worship - sacred fires maintained in fire temples as symbols of Ahura Mazda's presence
Yasna ceremony - primary liturgical ritual using the Avesta
Five daily prayers (gahs) facing light or sacred fire
Wearing the kusti (sacred cord) and sudreh (sacred shirt)
worship.temples: Fire temples (Atash Behram, Atash Adaran, Atash Dadgah) house eternally burning sacred fires
worship.priesthood: Mobeds (priests) maintain fires and perform ceremonies

primary.description: Hymns of Zoroaster - direct words of the prophet
Primary liturgical text of 72 chapters
Hymns to divine beings
Creation cosmology

secondary.description: Book of Kings - preserves pre-Islamic mythology

quotations.text: In the beginning, there were two spirits, twins, who revealed themselves through thought, word, and deed. Of these two, the wise chose rightly, the foolish did not.
The happiness and joy thou grantest through thy glorious fire is like unto the sun's light when it rises up in glory.

extendedContent.etymology: Ahura = "Lord" (cognate with Sanskrit Asura), Mazda = "Wisdom" (cognate with Greek Mnemosyne). Thus "Wise Lord" or "Lord of Wisdom".
extendedContent.attributes: Omniscient, omnipotent within good, uncreated, eternal, source of Asha, creator of Amesha Spentas
extendedContent.theologicalSignificance: Represents the first clear expression of ethical monotheism. Influenced Jewish, Christian, and Islamic concepts of God.
extendedContent.iconography: Represented by the Faravahar (winged disk) - symbolizing the divine glory (khvarenah) and the soul's journey toward truth.
extendedContent.modernPractice: Worshipped by Zoroastrians in Iran, India (Parsis), and diaspora communities worldwide.

subtitle: The Bounteous Immortals
name: ‚ú® Amesha Spentas
summary: Also known as ‚ú® Amesha Spentas. Associated with unknown.

search.searchableText: ‚ú® amesha spentas the bounteous immortals ‚ú® amesha spentas amesha spentas

extracted_lists: Water: Maintained and protected by Haurvatat
Earth: Nurtured and sustained by Spenta Armaiti
Plants: Given life and regeneration by Ameretat
Animals: Protected and guided by Vohu Manah
Fire/Light: Manifested and preserved by Asha Vahishta
Humanity: Directly created and guided by Ahura Mazda
Vohu Manah: Care for cattle and livestock
Asha Vahishta: Maintaining sacred fires, burning incense
Khshathra Vairya: Just rule, protecting the weak
Spenta Armaiti: Tending gardens, protecting earth
Haurvatat: Keeping waters pure, water libations
icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: ‚ú® Amesha Spentas is the bounteous immortals in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.narrative: The Amesha Spentas ("Bounteous Immortals") are the seven divine emanations of Ahura Mazda, representing his key attributes. They are both aspects of God and distinct divine beings who protect different elements of creation.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Each Amesha Spenta protects one of the seven creations and embodies a divine virtue.

dualism.role: Champions of Ahura Mazda against the forces of evil
dualism.opposition: Each Amesha Spenta has a demonic counterpart that they fight
dualism.function: Protect creation from corruption, embody divine virtues

practices: Each day of the month dedicated to an Amesha Spenta
Invoked in prayers and rituals
Seven creations cared for as sacred
worship.significance: Humans can embody the virtues of the Amesha Spentas through right living

primary.chapters: Yasna 28, 47, 51 - Zoroaster's hymns mention the Amesha Spentas

primary.description: Worship in Seven Chapters

quotations.text: By His Holy Spirit, by Best Thought, Word, and Deed, in accordance with Right, Mazda Ahura shall give Dominion, Welfare, and Immortality.

extendedContent.theologicalFunction: Bridge between transcendent God and creation; model virtues for humans
extendedContent.correspondences: Each connected to an element, a virtue, a color, and a day of the month
extendedContent.influence: May have influenced Jewish/Christian concepts of archangels

subtitle: Goddess of Waters, Fertility, and Healing

attributes.titles: Lady of the Waters, The Immaculate One, Strong and Holy, Mother of Life
attributes.symbols: Flowing water, Golden vessel/jug, Lotus, Eight-pointed star, Dove
attributes.sacred plants: Lotus, Rose, Pomegranate, Water lily, Myrtle
attributes.domains: Waters, Fertility, Healing, Purification, Abundance, Childbirth, Victory

gridDisplay.subtitle: Goddess of Waters, Fertility, and Healing
gridDisplay.title: üíß Anahita

name: üíß Anahita

listDisplay.primary: üíß Anahita - Goddess of Waters, Fertility, and Healing

family.consorts: Some traditions associate her with Mithra (sun/water duality)
family.parents: Created by Ahura Mazda as a yazata

summary: Also known as Anahita (Aredvi Sura Anahita). Associated with Lady of the Waters, The Immaculate One, Strong and Holy. Known by the epithets: Lady of the Waters.

search.searchableText: üíß anahita goddess of waters, fertility, and healing üíß anahita anahita

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: üíß Anahita is goddess of waters, fertility, and healing in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Anahita (Aredvi Sura Anahita - "moist, mighty, immaculate") is the yazata of waters, fertility, and wisdom. She is the source of all world waters, flowing from Mount Hara to purify the earth. She is depicted as a beautiful maiden in golden raiment.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Protector of all waters - rivers, lakes, seas. Source of fertility and abundance. Purifier of seed and womb. Associated with the planet Venus.
mythologyNarrative.importance: One of the most worshipped yazatas, with temples throughout the Persian Empire.

dualism.role: Ally of Ahura Mazda, protector of the waters against Angra Mainyu's corruption
dualism.function: Maintains the purity of waters which Angra Mainyu tried to pollute
dualism.symbolism: Pure, life-giving waters represent truth and fertility against chaos

practices: Water purification rituals
Prayers at rivers and springs
Offerings for fertility and childbirth
worship.temples: Major temples at Istakhr (Persepolis region), Kangavar, Shiz
worship.iconography: Beautiful maiden, golden crown, golden earrings, beaver-skin cloak, four-horse chariot

primary.description: Primary hymn to Anahita - describes her beauty and powers

quotations.text: Aredvi Sura Anahita drives in a chariot pulled by four white horses: wind, rain, cloud, and sleet. Her chariot runs swiftly, bearing boons to those who invoke her.

extendedContent.royalPatronage: Artaxerxes II promoted Anahita worship alongside Ahura Mazda
extendedContent.modernPractice: Water remains sacred in Zoroastrianism; polluting water is a serious sin

subtitle: The Destructive Spirit, Lord of Darkness
name: Mainyu

gridDisplay.title: Mainyu
gridDisplay.subtitle: The Destructive Spirit, Lord of Darkness

attributes.associated creatures: Serpents, scorpions, wolves, vermin, all venomous creatures
attributes.titles: Destructive Spirit, Ahriman, Adversary, Father of Lies, Lord of Darkness
attributes.manifestations: Disease, suffering, natural disasters, moral corruption, ignorance
attributes.domains: Druj(Lie), Darkness, Death, Disease, Chaos, Destruction

listDisplay.primary: Mainyu - The Destructive Spirit, Lord of Darkness

summary: Also known as üî• Angra Mainyu (Ahriman). Associated with Destructive Spirit, Ahriman, Adversary. Known by the epithets: Destructive Spirit.

search.searchableText: mainyu the destructive spirit, lord of darkness mainyu

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: Mainyu is the destructive spirit, lord of darkness in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Angra Mainyu (Ahriman in Middle Persian) is the uncreated spirit of evil, dwelling eternally in infinite darkness below the Void. Unlike Ahura Mazda, he lacked omniscience and remained ignorant of the good creation until he discovered it and attacked in envy.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: The Destructive Spirit who introduced evil, death, disease, and suffering into creation. He cannot create, only corrupt and destroy what Ahura Mazda has made.
mythologyNarrative.eschatology: At Frashokereti, Angra Mainyu will be utterly destroyed along with all evil, never to exist again.

dualism.nature: The embodiment of Druj (Lie/Chaos) in cosmic opposition to Asha (Truth/Order)
dualism.conflict: Chose falsehood, darkness, and destruction when offered the choice to join in creating good. Declared eternal enmity against Ahura Mazda's creation.
dualism.stance: Embodies darkness, ignorance, destruction, chaos, and death.
dualism.cosmicAssault: Pierced the sky to enter material creation, introducing death, disease, and corruption. Killed the Primordial Bull and poisoned Gayomart (first human).
dualism.agents: Commands the Daevas (demons) including Az (Concupiscence), Aeshma (Wrath), and Druj (personified Lie).

worship.note: Angra Mainyu is not worshipped but opposed. All Zoroastrian practice aims to fight evil.
worship.demons: The Daevas serve Angra Mainyu and are combated through prayers, rituals, and righteous living.

primary.chapters: Yasna 30, 32, 45 - describes the primordial choice and cosmic conflict

primary.description: Laws against demons - details methods of opposing evil
Describes the assault on creation and eventual defeat

quotations.text: These two spirits, the twins, revealed themselves first in a dream: in thought, word, and deed they are the Better and the Bad.
Angra Mainyu declared: "I will not agree with you, I will not praise your creation. I will destroy your creation forever and ever."

extendedContent.etymology: Angra = "destructive, evil", Mainyu = "spirit, mind". Thus "Destructive Spirit" or "Evil Mind".
extendedContent.characteristics: Ignorant (unlike omniscient Ahura Mazda), destructive, deceitful, sterile (cannot create), ultimately doomed
extendedContent.theologicalSignificance: Represents the origin of evil as a cosmic principle that is ultimately defeated, not eternal.
extendedContent.manifestations: Disease, death, drought, natural disasters, moral corruption, lies, violence
extendedContent.modernUnderstanding: Symbol of all that opposes truth, life, and righteousness. Fought through ethical living.

subtitle: Yazata of Fire
name: Atar
icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: Atar is yazata of fire in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.period: Central to Zoroastrianism from earliest texts
mythologyNarrative.narrative: Atar is the yazata of fire, called the "son of Ahura Mazda." Fire is the visible presence of Ahura Mazda in the material world - pure, purifying, and incorruptible. Unlike other elements, fire cannot be defiled by Angra Mainyu.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Divine presence in material creation, warrior against darkness, purifier of all things. Fire links the spiritual and physical realms.
mythologyNarrative.importance: Fire is the most sacred element in Zoroastrianism, maintained eternally in fire temples.

dualism.role: Champion against Angra Mainyu and the forces of darkness
dualism.function: Cannot be corrupted by evil; actively purifies creation
dualism.battle: The Avesta describes Atar battling the dragon Azi Dahaka (Zahhak)
dualism.symbolism: Light against darkness, truth against lies, purity against corruption

practices: Fire temples maintain sacred fires continuously burning
Daily prayers performed facing fire
Offerings of sandalwood and frankincense to fire
Never allowing fire to become impure
worship.temples: Three grades: Atash Behram (Victory Fire), Atash Adaran, Atash Dadgah
taboos: Never blow on fire (uses breath which can contaminate)

primary.description: Prayer to Fire - recited before sacred fire
Multiple references to fire's sacred nature
Fire's role in creation and final purification

quotations.text: We worship the Fire, O Ahura Mazda, thy son, swift, efficacious, powerful.

extendedContent.etymology: Atar from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ƒÅtar-, cognate with Latin atrium
extendedContent.vedicParallel: Cognate with Vedic Agni - both fire deities with similar sacred functions

fireGrades.name: Atash Behram
fireGrades.description: Highest grade - "victorious fire" - requires 16 different fire sources

fireGrades.name: Atash Adaran
fireGrades.description: Fire of fires - four fires combined

extendedContent.eschatology: At Frashokereti, molten metal (fire) will purify the entire earth

listDisplay.primary: Mithra - God of Covenants, Light, and Justice

family.parents: Created by Ahura Mazda as a yazata
family.consorts: None explicitly stated; some traditions associate with Anahita

subtitle: God of Covenants, Light, and Justice

gridDisplay.title: Mithra
gridDisplay.subtitle: God of Covenants, Light, and Justice

name: Mithra

attributes.titles: Lord of Wide Pastures, Ruler of the Covenant, Judge of Souls, Watchful Guardian
attributes.domains: Contracts, Oaths, Light, Sun, Justice, Truth, War, Protection
attributes.symbols: Rising sun, Rays of light, Mace (gada), Bull, Lotus
attributes.sacred animals: Bull, Horse (especially white horses), Boar, Ram

summary: Also known as Mithra (Mithras). Associated with Lord of Wide Pastures, Ruler of the Covenant, Judge of Souls. Known by the epithets: Lord of Wide Pastures.

search.searchableText: mithra god of covenants, light, and justice mithra

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: The yazata of contracts, oaths, and the rising sun. Mithra is the divine judge who witnesses all agreements and punishes oath-breakers. He sees all truth and illuminates the world with both physical light and moral clarity.

mythologyNarrative.origin: Ancient Iran and India (shared Indo-Iranian deity)
mythologyNarrative.narrative: Mithra is the yazata (divine being) of covenants, contracts, truth, and the rising sun. He is the divine witness to all oaths and agreements, punishing oath-breakers with death. He rides across the sky in a chariot drawn by white horses, illuminating the world.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Guardian of truth and contracts, divine judge who weighs souls at the Chinvat Bridge alongside Rashnu and Sraosha. Associated with the sun's light as both physical illumination and moral clarity.
mythologyNarrative.spread: Mithra's cult spread throughout the Roman Empire as Mithraism, a mystery religion popular among soldiers.

dualism.role: Ally of Ahura Mazda in the cosmic struggle
dualism.function: Enforces truth (Asha) by punishing those who break oaths (Druj)
dualism.judgment: One of three judges at the Chinvat Bridge who determine souls' fates
dualism.symbolism: Light that exposes falsehood and illuminates truth

practices: Dawn prayers when Mithra's light first appears
Covenant-making ceremonies invoking Mithra as witness
Mehr Yasht - hymn dedicated to Mithra
worship.temples: In Mithraism (Roman), underground temples (Mithraea) with tauroctony imagery
worship.iconography: Rising sun, rays of light, white horses, mace (for punishing oath-breakers), lotus

primary.description: Primary hymn to Mithra - describes his attributes and cosmic role
Various references throughout

quotations.text: Mithra, whose long arms seize the Lie, the covenant-breaking mortal, wherever he may be.
We worship Mithra of wide cattle-pastures, who has a thousand ears, ten thousand eyes.

extendedContent.vedic: Cognate with Vedic Mitra - the benevolent aspect of divine sovereignty
extendedContent.romanMithraism: Mystery cult spread through Roman Empire (1st-4th century CE), featuring bull-slaying (tauroctony) iconography
extendedContent.historicalInfluence: Christmas (December 25) may derive from Mithra's birthday - the rebirth of the unconquered sun

name: Ahura Mazda
title: Persian - Ahura Mazda
description: Also known as ‚ö° Ahura Mazda. Associated with Wise Lord, Lord of Wisdom, Creator of All. Known by the epithets: Wise Lord.

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">

</svg>

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Ahura Mazda (Ohrmazd in Middle Persian) is the uncreated, omniscient, supreme deity of Zoroastrianism. He existed eternally in infinite light above the Void, possessing complete knowledge of past, present, and future. He is the source of all good creation and the ultimate embodiment of Asha (Truth/Righteousness).
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Creator of all good things. He first created the world in spiritual form (menog), then manifested it in material form (getig). He emanated the seven Amesha Spentas as aspects of his divine nature to protect and govern creation.
mythologyNarrative.eschatology: At the end of time (Frashokereti), Ahura Mazda will achieve complete victory over evil, purifying all creation and establishing eternal paradise.

dualism.nature: Ethical/Cosmic Dualism - two primordial spirits who made opposite moral choices
dualism.conflict: Ahura Mazda chose Asha (Truth), Angra Mainyu chose Druj (Lie). Their cosmic struggle defines existence.
dualism.stance: Ahura Mazda embodies light, wisdom, creation, order, and life.
dualism.resolution: Good is destined to triumph. Evil will be annihilated at Frashokereti.
dualism.humanRole: Humans must choose to follow Asha, actively participating in the cosmic struggle through good thoughts, words, and deeds.

practices: Fire worship - sacred fires maintained in fire temples as symbols of Ahura Mazda's presence
Yasna ceremony - primary liturgical ritual using the Avesta
Five daily prayers (gahs) facing light or sacred fire
Wearing the kusti (sacred cord) and sudreh (sacred shirt)
worship.temples: Fire temples (Atash Behram, Atash Adaran, Atash Dadgah) house eternally burning sacred fires
worship.priesthood: Mobeds (priests) maintain fires and perform ceremonies

primary.description: Hymns of Zoroaster - direct words of the prophet
Primary liturgical text of 72 chapters
Hymns to divine beings
Creation cosmology

quotations.text: In the beginning, there were two spirits, twins, who revealed themselves through thought, word, and deed. Of these two, the wise chose rightly, the foolish did not.
The happiness and joy thou grantest through thy glorious fire is like unto the sun's light when it rises up in glory.

extendedContent.etymology: Ahura = "Lord" (cognate with Sanskrit Asura), Mazda = "Wisdom" (cognate with Greek Mnemosyne). Thus "Wise Lord" or "Lord of Wisdom".
extendedContent.attributes: Omniscient, omnipotent within good, uncreated, eternal, source of Asha, creator of Amesha Spentas
extendedContent.theologicalSignificance: Represents the first clear expression of ethical monotheism. Influenced Jewish, Christian, and Islamic concepts of God.
extendedContent.iconography: Represented by the Faravahar (winged disk) - symbolizing the divine glory (khvarenah) and the soul's journey toward truth.
extendedContent.modernPractice: Worshipped by Zoroastrians in Iran, India (Parsis), and diaspora communities worldwide.

name: Anahita
title: Persian - Anahita
description: Also known as Anahita (Aredvi Sura Anahita). Associated with Lady of the Waters, The Immaculate One, Strong and Holy. Known by the epithets: Lady of the Waters.

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Anahita (Aredvi Sura Anahita - "moist, mighty, immaculate") is the yazata of waters, fertility, and wisdom. She is the source of all world waters, flowing from Mount Hara to purify the earth. She is depicted as a beautiful maiden in golden raiment.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Protector of all waters - rivers, lakes, seas. Source of fertility and abundance. Purifier of seed and womb. Associated with the planet Venus.
mythologyNarrative.importance: One of the most worshipped yazatas, with temples throughout the Persian Empire.

dualism.role: Ally of Ahura Mazda, protector of the waters against Angra Mainyu's corruption
dualism.function: Maintains the purity of waters which Angra Mainyu tried to pollute
dualism.symbolism: Pure, life-giving waters represent truth and fertility against chaos

practices: Water purification rituals
Prayers at rivers and springs
Offerings for fertility and childbirth
worship.temples: Major temples at Istakhr (Persepolis region), Kangavar, Shiz
worship.iconography: Beautiful maiden, golden crown, golden earrings, beaver-skin cloak, four-horse chariot

primary.description: Primary hymn to Anahita - describes her beauty and powers

quotations.text: Aredvi Sura Anahita drives in a chariot pulled by four white horses: wind, rain, cloud, and sleet. Her chariot runs swiftly, bearing boons to those who invoke her.

extendedContent.royalPatronage: Artaxerxes II promoted Anahita worship alongside Ahura Mazda
extendedContent.modernPractice: Water remains sacred in Zoroastrianism; polluting water is a serious sin

name: Angra Mainyu
title: Persian - Angra Mainyu

relatedEntities.name: Bridge Chinvat Bridge Where souls are judged

description: Also known as üî• Angra Mainyu (Ahriman). Associated with Destructive Spirit, Ahriman, Adversary. Known by the epithets: Destructive Spirit.
icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>

mythologyNarrative.narrative: Angra Mainyu (Ahriman in Middle Persian) is the uncreated spirit of evil, dwelling eternally in infinite darkness below the Void. Unlike Ahura Mazda, he lacked omniscience and remained ignorant of the good creation until he discovered it and attacked in envy.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: The Destructive Spirit who introduced evil, death, disease, and suffering into creation. He cannot create, only corrupt and destroy what Ahura Mazda has made.
mythologyNarrative.eschatology: At Frashokereti, Angra Mainyu will be utterly destroyed along with all evil, never to exist again.

dualism.nature: The embodiment of Druj (Lie/Chaos) in cosmic opposition to Asha (Truth/Order)
dualism.conflict: Chose falsehood, darkness, and destruction when offered the choice to join in creating good. Declared eternal enmity against Ahura Mazda's creation.
dualism.stance: Embodies darkness, ignorance, destruction, chaos, and death.
dualism.cosmicAssault: Pierced the sky to enter material creation, introducing death, disease, and corruption. Killed the Primordial Bull and poisoned Gayomart (first human).
dualism.agents: Commands the Daevas (demons) including Az (Concupiscence), Aeshma (Wrath), and Druj (personified Lie).

worship.note: Angra Mainyu is not worshipped but opposed. All Zoroastrian practice aims to fight evil.
worship.demons: The Daevas serve Angra Mainyu and are combated through prayers, rituals, and righteous living.

primary.chapters: Yasna 30, 32, 45 - describes the primordial choice and cosmic conflict

primary.description: Laws against demons - details methods of opposing evil
Describes the assault on creation and eventual defeat

quotations.text: These two spirits, the twins, revealed themselves first in a dream: in thought, word, and deed they are the Better and the Bad.
Angra Mainyu declared: "I will not agree with you, I will not praise your creation. I will destroy your creation forever and ever."

extendedContent.etymology: Angra = "destructive, evil", Mainyu = "spirit, mind". Thus "Destructive Spirit" or "Evil Mind".
extendedContent.characteristics: Ignorant (unlike omniscient Ahura Mazda), destructive, deceitful, sterile (cannot create), ultimately doomed
extendedContent.theologicalSignificance: Represents the origin of evil as a cosmic principle that is ultimately defeated, not eternal.
extendedContent.manifestations: Disease, death, drought, natural disasters, moral corruption, lies, violence
extendedContent.modernUnderstanding: Symbol of all that opposes truth, life, and righteousness. Fought through ethical living.

name: Atar
title: Persian - Atar
icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>
description: Atar is a deity in persian mythology.

mythologyNarrative.period: Central to Zoroastrianism from earliest texts
mythologyNarrative.narrative: Atar is the yazata of fire, called the "son of Ahura Mazda." Fire is the visible presence of Ahura Mazda in the material world - pure, purifying, and incorruptible. Unlike other elements, fire cannot be defiled by Angra Mainyu.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Divine presence in material creation, warrior against darkness, purifier of all things. Fire links the spiritual and physical realms.
mythologyNarrative.importance: Fire is the most sacred element in Zoroastrianism, maintained eternally in fire temples.

dualism.role: Champion against Angra Mainyu and the forces of darkness
dualism.function: Cannot be corrupted by evil; actively purifies creation
dualism.battle: The Avesta describes Atar battling the dragon Azi Dahaka (Zahhak)
dualism.symbolism: Light against darkness, truth against lies, purity against corruption

practices: Fire temples maintain sacred fires continuously burning
Daily prayers performed facing fire
Offerings of sandalwood and frankincense to fire
Never allowing fire to become impure
worship.temples: Three grades: Atash Behram (Victory Fire), Atash Adaran, Atash Dadgah
taboos: Never blow on fire (uses breath which can contaminate)

primary.description: Prayer to Fire - recited before sacred fire
Multiple references to fire's sacred nature
Fire's role in creation and final purification

quotations.text: We worship the Fire, O Ahura Mazda, thy son, swift, efficacious, powerful.

extendedContent.etymology: Atar from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ƒÅtar-, cognate with Latin atrium
extendedContent.vedicParallel: Cognate with Vedic Agni - both fire deities with similar sacred functions

fireGrades.name: Atash Behram
fireGrades.description: Highest grade - "victorious fire" - requires 16 different fire sources

fireGrades.name: Atash Adaran
fireGrades.description: Fire of fires - four fires combined

extendedContent.eschatology: At Frashokereti, molten metal (fire) will purify the entire earth

name: Mithra
title: Persian - Mithra

children:
all righteous beings
enemies: all daevas

all righteous beings
enemies: all daevas

description: Also known as Mithra (Mithras). Associated with Lord of Wide Pastures, Ruler of the Covenant, Judge of Souls. Known by the epithets: Lord of Wide Pastures.
icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#8b7fff" opacity="0.2"/>
  <path d="M 32 12.8 L 44.8 51.2 L 19.2 51.2 Z" fill="#8b7fff"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="9.6" fill="#9370DB"/>
  <text x="32" y="57.6" text-anchor="middle" font-size="19.2" fill="#8b7fff">‚ö°</text>
</svg>

mythologyNarrative.origin: Ancient Iran and India (shared Indo-Iranian deity)
mythologyNarrative.narrative: Mithra is the yazata (divine being) of covenants, contracts, truth, and the rising sun. He is the divine witness to all oaths and agreements, punishing oath-breakers with death. He rides across the sky in a chariot drawn by white horses, illuminating the world.
mythologyNarrative.cosmicRole: Guardian of truth and contracts, divine judge who weighs souls at the Chinvat Bridge alongside Rashnu and Sraosha. Associated with the sun's light as both physical illumination and moral clarity.
mythologyNarrative.spread: Mithra's cult spread throughout the Roman Empire as Mithraism, a mystery religion popular among soldiers.

dualism.role: Ally of Ahura Mazda in the cosmic struggle
dualism.function: Enforces truth (Asha) by punishing those who break oaths (Druj)
dualism.judgment: One of three judges at the Chinvat Bridge who determine souls' fates
dualism.symbolism: Light that exposes falsehood and illuminates truth

practices: Dawn prayers when Mithra's light first appears
Covenant-making ceremonies invoking Mithra as witness
Mehr Yasht - hymn dedicated to Mithra
worship.temples: In Mithraism (Roman), underground temples (Mithraea) with tauroctony imagery
worship.iconography: Rising sun, rays of light, white horses, mace (for punishing oath-breakers), lotus

primary.description: Primary hymn to Mithra - describes his attributes and cosmic role
Various references throughout

quotations.text: Mithra, whose long arms seize the Lie, the covenant-breaking mortal, wherever he may be.
We worship Mithra of wide cattle-pastures, who has a thousand ears, ten thousand eyes.

extendedContent.vedic: Cognate with Vedic Mitra - the benevolent aspect of divine sovereignty
extendedContent.romanMithraism: Mystery cult spread through Roman Empire (1st-4th century CE), featuring bull-slaying (tauroctony) iconography
extendedContent.historicalInfluence: Christmas (December 25) may derive from Mithra's birthday - the rebirth of the unconquered sun
